Is there a better way to avoid unsafe in the value domain when using lean to perform NbPE for λβη\lambda_{\beta\eta}λβη​-calculus :

inductive VarId : Type :=
 | Str : String -> VarId
 | Level : Nat -> VarId -- de Bruijn level

open VarId

instance : BEq VarId where
  beq v₁ v₂ := match v₁, v₂ with
    | Str s₁, Str s₂ => s₁ == s₂
    | Level n₁, Level n₂ => n₁ == n₂
    | _, _ => false

instance : Repr VarId where
  reprPrec v i := match v with
    | Str s => s
    | Level n => "x" ++ reprPrec n i

inductive Term : Type :=
 | Var : VarId -> Term
 | App : Term -> Term -> Term
 | Lam : VarId -> Term -> Term

open Term

instance : Inhabited Term where
  default := Var (Str "uninitialized")

def Term.repr (i : Nat) : Term -> Std.Format
  | Var v => reprPrec v i
  | App f a => "(" ++ f.repr i ++ " " ++ a.repr i ++ ")"
  | Lam v b => "(λ " ++ reprPrec v i ++ " . " ++ b.repr i ++ ")"

instance : Repr Term where
  reprPrec v i := Term.repr i v

def Var' (varId : VarId) : Nat -> Term :=
  fun _ => Var varId

def Lam' (f : VarId -> Nat -> Term) : Nat -> Term :=
  fun n =>
    let v := Level n
    Lam v (f v (n + 1))

def App' (f a : Nat -> Term) : Nat -> Term :=
  fun n => App (f n) (a n)

unsafe inductive Value : Type :=
  | Tm (tm: Nat -> Term)
  | Fn (fn : Value -> Value)

unsafe instance : Inhabited Value where
  default := Value.Tm (fun _ => Inhabited.default)

open Value

unsafe def Term.eval (r : VarId -> Value) : Term -> Value
  | Var v => r v
  | App f a => match f.eval r with
    | Fn f' => f' $ a.eval r
    | _ => panic! "expected function"
  | Lam v b => Fn $ fun a => b.eval fun v' => if v == v' then a else r v'

inductive LType : Type :=
  | Base : String → LType
  | Arr : LType -> LType -> LType

open LType

mutual
unsafe def reify : LType -> Value -> (Nat -> Term)
  | Base _, Tm tm => tm
  | Arr t₁ t₂, Fn f => Lam' $ fun v => reify t₂ (f $ reflect t₁ (Var' v))
  | _, _ => panic! "type mismatch"
unsafe def reflect : LType -> (Nat -> Term) -> Value
  | Base _, tm => Tm tm
  | Arr t₁ t₂, e =>
    Fn $ fun a => reflect t₂ (App' e (reify t₁ a))
end

unsafe def norm (t : LType) (e : Term) :=
  reify t (e.eval (fun _ => panic! "unbound variable"))

-- λ f x . (λ y . f y) (f x)
unsafe def test :=
  norm (Arr (Arr (Base "a") (Base "b")) (Arr (Base "a") (Base "b")))
  (Lam (Str "f") (Lam (Str "x") (App (Lam (Str "y") (App (Var (Str "f")) (Var (Str "y"))))
  (App (Var (Str "f")) (Var (Str "x"))))))

#eval test 0

I don't think it can be done. As some evidence, consider that eval does not use typing information at all, and as a result it executes like an untyped lambda calculus evaluator:

unsafe def test :=
  norm (Base "a")
  (App
    (Lam (Str "x") (App (Var (Str "x")) (Var (Str "x"))))
    (Lam (Str "x") (App (Var (Str "x")) (Var (Str "x")))))
-- stack overflow

Therefore the denotational semantics for these terms cannot be regular lean functions, and so Value really does have to be unsafe because it is not mathematically well defined. You can do it with a less "executable" encoding but my reading of https://www.cse.chalmers.se/~peterd/papers/Caminha.pdf (which I assume is your reference) is that this is kind of the point

There is also the following remark, which looks pertinent:

Remark 1. It would be possible to let E be an object-type-indexed set family, as in the previous section, rather than a single set. We will not pursue such an approach for two reasons, though. First, for practical applications, it is important that correctness of the algorithm can be established in a straightforward way even when it is expressed in a non-dependently typed functional language. And second, there are additional complications in expressing the normalization algorithm for the call-by-value setting in the next section in a dependent-typed setting. The problems have to do with the interaction between computational effects such as continuations with a dependent type structure; at the time of writing, we do not have a viable dependently-typed algorithm for that case.

I got a version of this code working for typed STLC lambda terms:

inductive VarId : Type :=
  | Str : String → VarId
  | Level : Nat → VarId -- de Bruijn level
  deriving DecidableEq, Inhabited
open VarId

instance : BEq VarId where
  beq v₁ v₂ := match v₁, v₂ with
    | Str s₁, Str s₂ => s₁ == s₂
    | Level n₁, Level n₂ => n₁ == n₂
    | _, _ => false

instance : Repr VarId where
  reprPrec v i := match v with
    | Str s => s
    | Level n => "x" ++ reprPrec n i

inductive LType : Type :=
  | Base : String → LType
  | Arr : LType → LType → LType
  deriving DecidableEq, Inhabited

def LType.repr : LType → Std.Format
  | Base A => f!"{A}"
  | Arr A B => f!"({A.repr} → {B.repr})"

instance : Repr LType where
  reprPrec v _ := LType.repr v

open LType

inductive Term : Type :=
 | Var : VarId → Term
 | App : Term → Term → Term
 | Lam : VarId → LType → Term → Term

open Term

instance : Inhabited Term where
  default := Var (Str "uninitialized")

def Term.repr : Term → Std.Format
  | Var v => _root_.repr v
  | App f a => "(" ++ f.repr ++ " " ++ a.repr ++ ")"
  | Lam v t b => f!"(λ {_root_.repr v} : {t.repr} . {b.repr})"

instance : Repr Term where
  reprPrec v _ := Term.repr v

def Var' (varId : VarId) : Nat → Term :=
  fun _ => Var varId

def Lam' (τ : LType) (f : VarId → Nat → Term) : Nat → Term :=
  fun n =>
    let v := Level n
    Lam v τ (f v (n + 1))

def App' (f a : Nat → Term) : Nat → Term :=
  fun n => App (f n) (a n)

def Value : LType → Type
  | Base _ => Nat → Term
  | Arr t₁ t₂ => Value t₁ → Value t₂

def Value.default : ∀ {τ}, Value τ
  | Base _ => fun _ => Inhabited.default
  | Arr _ _ => fun _ => default

instance {τ} : Inhabited (Value τ) where
  default := Value.default

inductive TTerm : (VarId → LType) → LType → Type
  | var (v) : TTerm T (T v)
  | app : TTerm T (Arr τ₁ τ₂) → TTerm T τ₁ → TTerm T τ₂
  | lam (v τ₁) : TTerm (fun v' => if v = v' then τ₁ else T v') τ₂ → TTerm T (Arr τ₁ τ₂)

instance : Inhabited (Σ τ, TTerm T τ) where
  default := ⟨_, .var default⟩

def TTerm.toTerm : TTerm T τ → Term
  | .var v => Var v
  | .app t₁ t₂ => App t₁.toTerm t₂.toTerm
  | .lam v τ b => Lam v τ b.toTerm

def Term.toTTerm : Term → Σ τ, TTerm T τ
  | Var v => ⟨_, .var v⟩
  | App t₁ t₂ =>
    match t₁.toTTerm with
    | ⟨Arr τ₁ τ₂, t₁⟩ =>
      let ⟨τ₁', t₂⟩ := t₂.toTTerm
      if h : τ₁ = τ₁' then ⟨τ₂, .app t₁ (h ▸ t₂)⟩ else panic! "type mismatch"
    | _ => panic! "type mismatch"
  | Lam v τ₁ b =>
    let ⟨_, b⟩ := b.toTTerm
    ⟨_, .lam v τ₁ b⟩

def TTerm.eval (r : (v : VarId) → Value (T v)) : TTerm T τ → Value τ
  | .var v => r v
  | .app f a => (f.eval r) (a.eval r)
  | .lam (τ₁ := τ₁) v b => fun a => b.eval fun v' =>
    if h : v = v' then by simp [h]; exact a else by simp [h]; exact r v'

mutual
def reify : ∀ τ, Value τ → (Nat → Term)
  | Base _, tm => tm
  | Arr t₁ t₂, f => Lam' t₁ fun v => reify t₂ (f $ reflect t₁ (Var' v))
def reflect : ∀ τ, (Nat → Term) → Value τ
  | Base _, tm => tm
  | Arr t₁ t₂, e => fun a => reflect t₂ (App' e (reify t₁ a))
end

def norm (e : Term) :=
  let ⟨t, e⟩ := Term.toTTerm (T := fun _ => default) e
  reify t (e.eval (fun _ => panic! "unbound variable"))

-- λ f x . (λ y . f y) (f x)
def test :=
  norm <|
  Lam (Str "f") (Arr (Base "a") (Base "a")) <|
  Lam (Str "x") (Base "a") <|
  App
    (Lam (Str "y") (Base "a") (App (Var (Str "f")) (Var (Str "y"))))
    (App (Var (Str "f")) (Var (Str "x")))

#eval test 0

Without having types in the lambdas, I'm not sure how to write the typechecking stage Term.toTTerm, even given a top level type annotation, because you can have terms like (λ x. e) x : A where the type of x is unbound
You could probably do a more complex type inference algorithm like algorithm W but it doesn't seem to be the focus here

I'm quite late to this party, but there is a standard solution to this problem (due to Andreas Abel): instead of using a Lean-closure at Fn (fn : Value -> Value), represent closures as an object-level Term together with a stack of arguments for all its variables except one binder. See e.g. here for an explanation.

As a side note, I feel like not strictly-positive inductives should be some kind of partial rather than unsafe: code that uses these shouldn't have any type-safety issues (ordinary non-terminating languages with ADTs support them); the non-positivity is only an obstacle to reasoning.
partial is not supposed to compromise logical consistency, but non-positive inductives do

with regular partial defs, this is worked around by having you separately prove the type is inhabited. For a partial inductive, you would need to prove the type is not contradictory to have. I think if you said that the inductive type was opaque, this would work for the type and its constructors, but you would run into trouble with the recursor. One way to fix this would be to restrict the recursor to only apply when the motive type is inhabited

Besides liar-paradox style inductives, you also need to rule out cantor-paradox style inductives and that means noConfusion should not be provable and the constructors are not disjoint. That means the recursor cannot have an iota rule

I think with those two modifications, you can safely have partial inductive. We can always model any inductive as a unit type, where every constructor just ignores all its arguments and returns the unit value, and the recursor also ignores all its arguments and returns the default value for the motive, and there is no iota rule so you cannot observe that the definitions are weird.

ex:

-- partial inductive Liar : Type where
--   | mk : (Liar → False) → Liar

opaque LiarPT : NonemptyType

def Liar : Type := LiarPT.type

noncomputable opaque Liar.mk : (Liar → False) → Liar :=
  fun _ => Classical.choice LiarPT.property

@[elab_as_elim]
noncomputable opaque Liar.rec.{u} : ∀ {motive : Liar → Sort u},
  (∀ (a : Liar → False), motive (Liar.mk a)) → ∀ (t : Liar) [Nonempty (motive t)], motive t :=
  fun _ _ h => Classical.choice h
